Award.AwardTitle: IRNC: SP: International Research Instrumentation System (IRIS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The International Research Instrumentation System (IRIS) is a proposal to provide a software framework to simplify the task of end-to-end network performance monitoring and diagnostics and thereby improve support for international science and engineering collaborations. IRIS will deliver a comprehensive monitoring package that will benefit each IRNC awardee as well as the entire project as a whole by delivering instant access to information that will reveal the status and health of any participating network.

IRIS facilitates a broader deployment of perfSONAR enabled resources significantly increasing the likelihood diagnostic resources will be available along the end-to-end paths needed by researchers relying on high-performance international network connections. As a result, NSF-funded science efforts, such as those within Very Long Baseline Interferometry (eVLBI), the Global Environment for Network Innovations (GENI), and the Laser Interferometer Gravitational Wave Observatory (LIGO), are more likely to be able to exploit available network resources by improving their network performance.

This proposal will have significant impact on the broad international science and engineering network user community by providing key measurement tools with global applicability. IRIS will advance the state of network measurement and monitoring by working with IRNC projects to research and implement solutions to challenging network measurement problems. This to have a broad impact among multiple scientific disciplines involving global collaboration and exchange of large data sets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Research Instrumentation System (IRIS) project has provided an effective software framework to simplify the task of end-to-end network performance monitoring and diagnostics, thereby improving support for international science and engineering collaborations.  The IRIS project has allowed projects within NSF’s International Research Network Connections (IRNC) initiative to meet network measurement and monitoring requirements, enhancing the delivery of mature and capable measurement software that is immediately available for use in production environments. The project also has built upon the existing perfSONAR-PS software framework (an internationally recognized tool focused on deployment of efficient and standardized mechanisms for the collection, storage, and exchange of network related performance measurements) to integrate the performance monitoring needs required of IRNC projects. This built upon Internet2’s lead role in developing perfSONAR-PS as a network performance monitoring system, and has benefited from successful adoption within Internet2 member institutions, regional connector networks, and peer networks. As a result, there has been substantial adoption of perfSONAR protocols among multi-national and international networks, international links, exchange points, campuses, and scientific disciplines.  The project's intellectual merit has involved its ability to leverage Internet2’s strong track record in facilitating collaboration and interaction among the international network community. By doing so, the project has had a broad impact by operating in and contributing significantly to an ever-changing environment that continues to evolve around standards, deployment, and technology.  It also has had a broad impact for the international science and engineering research community, as scientific collaborations and corresponding data become increasingly distributed globally and across disciplines, necessitating reliable reliable high-speed network performance.  It also has facilitated diagnosis and debugging of network performance issues that would not otherwise be possible within isolated, specific campus environments.  The project’s larger impact is the further advancement of perfSONAR measurement tools for use in the global research community when addressing cross-domain network issues.
